Comprehending that some people‚Äôs situations and experiences must be shelved or that they must begin a new phase is easier said than done. Compassion for ourselves and others can help us. The only way out is through! See you on the other side!

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Annular Solar Eclipse In Aquarius

Take note: February 17th is set to be a momentous day. According to lunar astrology, not only does it usher in the Year of the Fire Horse, but the solar eclipse in Aquarius also occurs at 7:01 a.m. EST. This is the first eclipse that falls on the Aquarius and Leo lunar axis, which makes its formal move into these signs on July 26th. The eclipse activates the coming North Node of Destiny in Aquarius, urging us to usher in a new mindset, and for us all to work cohesively to make global advances. We are a powerful force of nature when we come together.

A ‚Äúring of fire‚Äù annual solar eclipse is a rare lunar¬†phenomenon that is the result of the moon moving between the sun and earth, while being far from the earth, making the moon look smaller than the sun. The result of the eclipse leaves a fiery look to the circular edges of the moon (in this particular case, the moon will appear that way for two minutes and 20 seconds at the peak of the eclipse). The eclipse is primarily visible from Antarctica. Other regions, such as South America, South Africa, and the Indian Ocean, will have partial views.

The solar eclipse in Aquarius aspects a sensitive point of the sign, known as an anaretic degree (the 29th degree). The urgency to grow and evolve is immediate. It is giving us a chance to embrace our unique sentiments and let them be known. The collective is changing, and we are evolving our minds with it. Because the planet Uranus, which is in Taurus, is active in the eclipse, it‚Äôs fair to say that this is the time of revolution. We are going to stand up for what we believe in and won‚Äôt back down. The results may be unpredictable at the moment, but the battle is worth fighting for.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Total Lunar Eclipse In Virgo

On March 3rd at 6:38 a.m. EST, the total lunar eclipse in Virgo intensifies the sky, giving stargazers and astrology lovers an amazing sight to see and capture. The lunar eclipse is a time of release, since it connects to the South Node of Destiny in Virgo (on the current Pisces and Virgo lunar axis). We are departing from old views and emotions, making space for us to explore different philosophies. This is a moment of transcendence and reflection, so take a look back at what recently happened that is sparking a reaction that pushes us to run away from it.

During a total lunar eclipse, the moon appears to take on a reddish hue as it passes over the earth‚Äôs shadow. Known as the ‚ÄúBlood Moon,‚Äù total lunar eclipses are a moment of illumination and revelation. The lunar eclipse will be visible in the Western Americas, Australia, East Asia, and the Pacific Ocean, lasting around 59 minutes at its totality.

The lunar eclipse in Virgo receives a gentle push from Jupiter retrograde in Cancer, making a difference. Jupiter is known to be the planet of luck, but it can also expand matters that are in a delicate position in either good or bad ways. Problems can become bigger; however, Jupiter always ensures that the results are fortunate. The sting may feel intense at the moment, especially since Mercury retrograde in Pisces is causing ambiguity and confusion. Looking back on the eclipse, we‚Äôll realize that letting go of the past was necessary. The moon in Virgo is a creature of comfort, which is why relinquishing control and healing will be challenging. In the end, it‚Äôll be worth the sacrifice and ride.

I‚Äôll admit it, I‚Äôm a Type A person‚Äôs worst nightmare‚Ä¶ and I had every intention of staying that way. That is, until Hilton invited me on a press trip with a handful of seasoned travel reporters, people who don‚Äôt just travel, but optimize it. Over dinner, two of them walked me through how they use points to unlock upgrades, experiences, and thousands of dollars in savings I didn‚Äôt even realize I was leaving behind.

And for my fellow Type B travelers who‚Äôve been raw-dogging their way through travel, here‚Äôs how one Hilton-hosted weekend in West LA reformed me, without stripping away my go-with-the-flow energy.¬†

I had just moved from New York to Los Angeles when Hilton reached out to host my Grammy Awards weekend experience.I jumped at the opportunity to attend music‚Äôs biggest night and enjoy a little staycation.¬†

What I didn‚Äôt expect was horseback riding in Malibu, multi-course dinners on property, and a suite bigger than my NYC and LA apartments combined, all tied to Hilton Honors, the brand‚Äôs loyalty program that gives members access to curated Grammys weekend packages, upgrades, and experiences I genuinely did not know you could redeem with Points.

And before you roll your eyes at the word ‚Äúpoints,‚Äù I see you. Because if you‚Äôre anything like me, ‚Äúpoints‚Äù sounds like something that requires 47 international flights and a corporate job with unlimited PTO. I am here to tell you: it‚Äôs not as unattainable as it sounds. Let‚Äôs break it down.¬†

When you book direct or stay at Hilton properties, you earn points you can actually use, either toward free nights or by combining them with cash. You don‚Äôt need some impossible balance, you just use what you have.

But what surprised me most is that it‚Äôs not just about rooms. Through Hilton Honors Experiences, Points can unlock actual moments, concert access, VIP sporting events, spa treatments, even Grammy weekend stays at Waldorf Astoria Beverly Hills.

And then there are the small things that quietly upgrade your life: skipping the front desk with a digital key, choosing your room in advance, late checkout when you need it. And truuuust me, a girl like me will always need a late checkout.¬†

But what if you‚Äôre not headed to the Grammys? What if you just want a moment away from the noise?

That‚Äôs exactly how I ended up on the back of a horse overlooking the Malibu coastline. Hilton partnered with a local outfitter and handled the logistics, transportation, timing, the whole setup, so all I had to do was show up. It‚Äôs an experience I would never, ever plan for myself, but it pulled me completely out of my comfort zone in the best way.

We split our stay between Oceana Santa Monica and Waldorf Astoria Beverly Hills, and they could not have felt more different. The Oceana was rooted in serenity and calm, the type of energy Santa Monica is known for. And if you stay there, head downstairs to the La Monique and grab the Escargot Poppers with garlic herb cr√®me fra√Æche. Yes, they‚Äôre fried snails. And yes, they kind of remind me of mozzarella sticks. Soooo good.¬†

On the day of the Grammys, we stayed at the Waldorf Astoria Beverly Hills. It felt like a slightly elevated experience and definitely had me feeling like a superstar for the day. The bathroom overlooked the city, the suite was polished and luxurious, and everything about it felt Grammys-coded. When my mom came to visit, we definitely had a pinch me moment. We‚Äôre just two girls from the deep-south after all!¬†

All of this to say: points are¬† for everyone ‚Äî including you, Type B traveler who still loves chaos but doesn‚Äôt mind leveling up. We can still, stubbornly, embrace the chaos while making our money stretch.

title: Wuthering Heights‚Äô Margot Robbie Says Cathy & Isabella Fighting Over Heathcliff Was ‚ÄúRadical‚Äù
text:
Wuthering Heights‚Äô Margot Robbie Says Cathy & Isabella Fighting Over Heathcliff Was ‚ÄúRadical‚Äù

There‚Äôs a lot to talk about when it comes to Wuthering Heights. I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll be dissecting and debating it for weeks. From the whitewashing controversy to the toxic love to the daring costumes, the discourse is going to be discoursing. This film, like most everything Emerald Fennell touches, is going to be divisive. And I think that‚Äôs part of its charm and its weakness. As The Ringer put it, Wuthering Heights may be ‚Äúthe hate-watch event of the year.‚Äù Except, I didn‚Äôt hate it.¬†

I may be one of the few people that don‚Äôt think this Heathcliff should have been anything but the white fantasy Fennell envisioned (let her make the revitionist movie she wants; we should be championing artists of color to create their wildest desires onscreen and pushing Hollywood execs to greenlight them instead), and this may be strange to admit, considering the movie is based on one of the most toxic relationships in literature, but as soon as Cathy and Heathcliff grew into Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi, and they gave us some of the most blistering and intoxicating chemistry I‚Äôve seen onscreen in awhile, I started to enjoy myself.¬†I couldn‚Äôt look away.

Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights is a gothic, depressing tragedy of love, lust, loss, and self destruction and yet, it‚Äôs also kind of fun (until it‚Äôs not, no spoilers). Aside from the absurdity and campiness of the costumes, one of the things I enjoyed most was how unhinged, horny, and mean Cathy could be. And how weird and complicated Alison Oliver‚Äôs Isabella Linton was. As Robbie put it, Cathy is ‚Äúsuch a bitch.‚Äù You can say a lot about Fennell, but she can write female rage (see: Promising Young Woman) and here, she sets her sights on female desire.¬†

Late last month, the day after I‚Äôd seen Wuthering Heights for the first time, I talked to Robbie and Oliver at the film‚Äôs fantastical press junket (it was held at The Doheny Estate at the Greystone Mansion and Gardens and there were Wuthering Heights-themed installations throughout the historic grounds) about their characters‚Äô surprisingly refreshinging agency, that much-discussed Robbie-Elordi chemistry, and which costumes shocked them the most.

Both of these characters are messy. They‚Äôre destructive. They‚Äôre unapologetic. They put female desire first, which I think is going to piss some people off, but I loved that about them. It would be easy to say that their entire identities are wrapped up in romantic obsession. But talk about how important it was to show that female desire, that all consuming desire, and the choices that these women make for themselves?¬†

Margot Robbie: Do you know what felt radical? We have a scene ‚Äî Alison and I ‚Äî on the swing in the garden, and it‚Äôs a scene essentially, where we‚Äôre just fight over Heathcliff, and it felt so radical to do a scene like that. The ironic thing is that we‚Äôve fought so hard to not have to do that in movies anymore, but now it‚Äôs been so long since ‚Äî I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôve done a scene like this since I was on the soap opera I was on back in Australia when I was a teenager. It felt so radical to just be two women fighting over a man. It was crazy. ‚ÄúYou have him. He‚Äôs so handsome. Who you talking about? You could never take him!‚Äù It was weirdly exciting to do.

Alison Oliver: Yeah, it was strange. All of these characters do have ‚Äî I feel like Emerald really gave them agency in their own ways as well, which within the sort of confines or the period, you do feel like they have agency in some sense. And I think that was important to show.¬†

Absolutely. They have depth and agency.

MR: Yeah, they all make the choices. And then everything you see in the movie happens because of the choices they make. Whereas usually, even now, when we‚Äôre not doing scenes fighting about men, most of the time, you‚Äôre usually playing a character that something happens to, and then you watch a movie about the effects of that thing happening to that female character.¬†

AO: They are the decider.

MR: For both of our characters, I feel like we make a choice, we do a thing, and it‚Äôs not the right thing in most instances, and then we have to deal with the consequences.

OK, Margot, this does not work unless you and Jacob have the most insane chemistry we‚Äôve ever seen on screen. And you did. I‚Äôm always fighting to bring back chemistry, and you guys did it.¬†

MR: Yes! Chemistry and charisma are two things that I‚Äôm like, why can‚Äôt we have that? That‚Äôs what I want in the movies. Charismatic characters or I want insane chemistry,

Was there a moment where you and Jacob were like, Oh, we got it?

MR: There were a couple of moments. Even on day one. [We shot] the first scene in the movie where Cathy flings open the bed hangings, and [Heathcliff is] lying in bed. And then we ended up cutting this bit but I walked up over him, and then crouch down and got like this close to his face and told him to, ‚Äúget up, we‚Äôve got neighbors,‚Äù or whatever it was. And we cut that bit because the proximity is something we wanted to save. But, I mean, that was day one, and even then, everyone was kind of like, ‚ÄúWhoa.‚Äù And we were like, ‚ÄúOkay, I think this movie‚Äôs gonna work.‚Äù Also just because she‚Äôs throwing something at him, and he‚Äôs throwing it back, and he‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù There was already an intensity between them that I think we could build on from that point.¬†

Alison, what was it like watching Margot and Jacob build that chemistry?¬†

AO: Incredible. I kept feeling like I was watching, like an old Hollywood film, like watching Elizabeth Taylor and Montgomery Clift. It really was so incredible to see the two of them just inhabit those characters. It was really special.

We have to talk about the costumes. There were so many moments in my theater that the whole audience gasped at certain costumes. Were there any moments for both of you that you saw a costume you put on and it shocked you?¬†

AO: We had so many costume changes. Every time, in me and Margot‚Äôs rooms ‚Äî we were next to each other and they put us both in our rooms ‚Äî it would probably take like, half an hour to get into the outfit, and then we‚Äôd both come out of the room at the same time and do a reveal. I never felt like more of a girl in my life. I‚Äôd come out and be like, Ah!! [mimics screaming]!!¬†

MR: You couldn‚Äôt control that reaction if you wanted to. And I didn‚Äôt want to, but I couldn‚Äôt even if I had wanted to. It was so fun.

AO: [to Margot] Did you have a favorite?¬†

MR: I think my favorite was on the swing. That costume during the swing scene [was my favorite]. It‚Äôs got this black velvet bodice, and this like and this like neck thing, and then this bit‚Äôs showing, but then it‚Äôs like, got this chainwork in pink rose. We replicated these old couple of paintings of women in that outfit. One woman wore it, got painted in it, and then someone else was like, Well, I want that. And then did it as well. I think there‚Äôs three different decades apart where they‚Äôve done this. I was like, wow, that lady was the original Kardashian. Like, did she wear something and everyone was like, ‚ÄúI want to wear what she wore!‚Äù¬†

AO: There‚Äôs this shot where Margot is on the swing, and then I think Isabella says something, and [Cathy] twists around. And every time [she] did that, I literally was like, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the most beautiful thing I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù And I would break¬† character and be like [gasps].

I remember that scene. It‚Äôs also a bitchy moment.

MR: She‚Äôs such a bitch, and then swings back around [laughs].

This interview was edited and condensed for clarity.¬†

Wuthering Heights is in theaters now.

title: The Pitt‚Äôs Shabana Azeez Says One Random Act Of Kindness Launched Her Career
text:
The Pitt‚Äôs Shabana Azeez Says One Random Act Of Kindness Launched Her Career

When The Pitt‚Äôs Shabana Azeez talks about her career, she traces it back to a single,¬†almost accidental moment of kindness that allowed her to follow a dream that had always been inside her. ‚ÄúI got into acting because a lady was really nice to me one time,‚Äù she says, laughing. It sounds flippant, but it‚Äôs the truth. She grew up in a family where the arts were not encouraged, academics were the priority, and despite wanting to act her whole life, she never studied drama at school. It wasn‚Äôt until she was working at Mercury CX, an emerging filmmakers‚Äô hub in Adelaide, Australia, that someone finally asked her the right question.

Her boss pulled her aside. ‚ÄúShe said, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre great, but this isn‚Äôt your passion. What is it?‚Äô And I was like, ‚ÄòWell, I‚Äôd like to act, but I‚Äôve literally never acted before.'‚Äù Within an hour, her boss had secured her an audition for a short film, and she booked it, with no prior acting experience. That led her to secure roles in the animated Lesbian Space Princess and the coercive-control thriller Bird Eater. She expresses the same mix of gratitude as she talks about her leap from Australian indie television to HBO‚Äôs The Pitt. The contrast, she says, is both extreme and strangely familiar. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs chalk and cheese in some ways, and exactly the same in others,‚Äù she explains. The budgets are bigger, the access is better, on The Pitt, she can consult real doctors and benefit from an army of specialists, but the core remains unchanged. ‚ÄúEveryone cares about the story.‚Äù

When Shabana first read the script for The Pitt she described it as information overload. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like ten series regulars and then a bunch of recurring characters, and then all the patients, and all the names for the doctors are surnames. So you can‚Äôt be like, ‚ÄòWho‚Äôs a woman? Who‚Äôs a man? What are their age?‚Äô There‚Äôs no clues. I had to go out and buy more highlighters and color-code the entire script,‚Äù she says.¬†The audition process for The Pitt was surprisingly lowkey: a single self-tape, followed by a Zoom scheduled for twenty minutes that wrapped after just nine minutes. When the call ended early, she assumed it was a bad sign. ‚ÄúI cried for half an hour afterwards,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThe Zoom was nine minutes. The emotional recovery was three times that.‚Äù So when she landed the role, and learned the production would sponsor her visa and fly her halfway across the world it came as a genuine shock.

Moving to LA was, in her words, ‚Äúhorrible in so many ways‚Äù and yet also strangely exhilarating. There was a joy in not knowing what came next, in stepping into something undefined. ‚ÄúTo not know what you‚Äôre stepping into, and to have that curiosity, that scared feeling, that‚Äôs what life is about,‚Äù she says. Once in Los Angeles, the emotional weight of the move fully settled in. ‚ÄúOh my god, I knew no one,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI truly knew not a single person in LA.‚Äù That isolation became especially clear during her first days at work. Sitting at lunch during boot camp, she watched as coworkers casually texted friends and loved ones. ‚ÄúEverybody was texting their friends, and I was like, I have no friends to text. They‚Äôre all asleep,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThat was really lonely and really scary,‚Äù she adds.

Everything shifted when she formed a close friendship with co-star Supriya Ganesh, who plays Dr Samira Mohan. Their bond deepened quickly. ‚ÄúI adore her. I think the world of her,‚Äù she says simply. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my best friend.‚Äù That sense of shared experience extended into their professional lives as well. Shabana notes that her character wasn‚Äôt originally written to be South Asian, but the production pivoted after her audition. ‚ÄúI remember thinking that would never happen because they already had a ‚Äòbrown girl‚Äô,‚Äù she says, pointing to the unspoken limits that still shape representation on screen.

Season one was filmed in near-total anonymity. By season two, the shift was impossible to ignore. Filming now overlapped with awards season; days were spent on set, nights at the Golden Globes or Critics‚Äô Choice Awards. The pace was punishing. ‚ÄúI got flu-level sick three times,‚Äù she admits. Still, amid the noise and spectacle, the work itself never changed. ‚ÄúThe show is the same to make,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs really grounding.‚Äù In The Pitt, Shabana plays Victoria, a medical student, a role that could easily collapse into the familiar model minority archetype: hyper-competent, genius-level, and primarily functional. But Shabana was intent on resisting that flattening, shaping Victoria into a character defined as much by her flaws as her intelligence. ‚ÄúWhen we talk about excellence or prodigies, we tend to think, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs play that,‚Äô‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs not really how people work. When you‚Äôre very good at something, you usually have a deficit that‚Äôs just as powerful. For Victoria, it‚Äôs social. She‚Äôs deeply socially inept.‚Äù

What she loves most about acting is the research. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an exercise in empathy,‚Äù she says. Through projects like Bird Eater, where she researched stories of emotional abuse, she found it changed her not only as an actor, but as a person. ‚ÄúEvery woman I spoke to had a story. It genuinely changed my life.‚Äù Rather than focusing solely on the medical aspects of her role, she immersed herself in romance novels, glossy American teen dramas, and studies of loneliness. Victoria, she explains, is ‚Äúbuilding a life she doesn‚Äôt really want,‚Äù and fantasy becomes a form of escape. By Season Two, the show allows that internal tension to surface. ‚ÄúWe really dig into the icky parts, her jealousy, her exhaustion, her sharpness. She fails a lot. And I think that‚Äôs what actually dismantles the model minority myth.‚Äù

When I asked Shabana how she stays grounded amid the whirlwind success of The Pitt, she laughs. ‚ÄúMy little brother keeps me really grounded. Honestly, they kind of bully me about it, which is actually kind of helpful. When I went home for Christmas, every time I tried to speak and someone interrupted me, my brother would be like, ‚ÄòEverybody, excuse me ‚Äî Hollywood is trying to speak.‚Äô Before I said anything, my uncle would be like, ‚ÄòAction.‚Äô It‚Äôs that kind of teasing that reminds me it‚Äôs just a job.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt brings me back to earth. It‚Äôs meaningful work, but it‚Äôs art, it‚Äôs play, and it‚Äôs fun, it‚Äôs not brain surgery. I think there‚Äôs a real danger of people taking themselves too seriously, and my family bullying me actually really helps with that.‚Äù

Season 2 of The Pitt is now streaming on HBO MAX .

title: Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights Whitewashed Heathcliff & Honestly, It Was For The Best
text:
Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights Whitewashed Heathcliff & Honestly, It Was For The Best

Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights opens with a scene I hated so much, I almost walked out of the theater. Don‚Äôt worry, it goes up from there! The scene in question is a hanging. Two feet dangle from the gallows as an onlooker jokes about the lifeless body‚Äôs final unconscious act: a hard on. It‚Äôs mentioned later that the perpetrator was a rapist. So the glee in which the spectators (including Catherine ‚ÄúCathy‚Äù Earnshaw) gawk at his erect penis while he is strangled to death is justified. I understand the point ‚Äî that the story about to unfold is equal parts morbid, horny, irreverent, and uncomfortable ‚Äî but it just felt like a cheap ploy for shock and awe. The good news is that the rest of the film deals with these conflicting emotions slightly more effectively. And Catherine‚Äôs (played in her early years by Charlotte Mellington) curiosity for sex and macabre runs throughout the story, creating a fascinating duality of romance and toxicity, the things Emily Bront√´‚Äôs Wuthering Heights are known for. But this opening scene is very different from the book‚Äôs, and it was just one reason (of many) why I‚Äôm glad the Heathcliff in Emerald Fennell‚Äôs adaptation of Wuthering Heights is white.¬†

Depending on who you ask, Bront√´‚Äôs Heathcliff is supposed to be Black or Brown, since he‚Äôs described in the novel as a ‚Äúdark-skinned gypsy in aspect‚Äù and a ‚Äúdirty, ragged, black-haired child.‚Äù Another description: ‚Äúas dark almost as if it came from the devil.‚Äù In a piece for Vulture called Is Heathcliff White?, Jasmine Vojdani writes that, ‚ÄúThe idea that Heathcliff might be of African descent first entered academic discussion in the 1950s and gained momentum as postcolonial studies became more popular in the ‚Äô80s and ‚Äô90s. Scholars have argued that the proximity of Liverpool ‚Äî one of the biggest slave ports at the time in which Wuthering Heights is set ‚Äî to the Bront√´s‚Äô home in Haworth cannot be overlooked.‚Äù Vojdani interviews scholars and tries to get to the bottom of this mystery surrounding one of literature‚Äôs most famous leading men. One scholar says, ‚ÄúHe is both based on the boy of an Indian ruler who‚Äôd been orphaned because of the East India Company battles. But he‚Äôs also based on an Ashanti warrior‚Äôs son.‚Äù Another: ‚ÄúThe feeling that he should be of African heritage, I think that is interference coming in from [Bront√´] sister‚Äôs book. Because we do know that in Jane Eyre, Bertha Rochester is born in Jamaica.‚Äù Ultimately, Vojdani decides, ‚ÄúBy Victorian standards, he‚Äôs definitely not white ‚Äî and likely by ours as well. Is Heathcliff Black? Maybe! It is both historically and textually viable, but he isn‚Äôt necessarily Black.‚Äù¬†

We can debate Bront√´‚Äôs intentions for decades (and clearly, scholars have), but what‚Äôs true in this adaptation is that a white Australian man (Jacob Elordi) and a white British boy (Owen Cooper) play Heathcliff. After watching the film, honestly, it‚Äôs for the best. I am not encouraging whitewashing, which let‚Äôs be clear is exactly what this adaptation and many before it have done. Canonically, Heathcliff was not white so casting him as such is, in fact, whitewashing. But this is Fennell‚Äôs version of the story (I could write a whole other disseration on why she wasn‚Äôt the filmmaker to take on this adaptation) and aside from what implications could be drawn from a movie starring a Black man opening with a lynching, I just don‚Äôt think this love story is one I would want to see, or engage in the discourse, if it was a man of color seducing and obsessing over a white woman in this way.

When they are grownups, Heathcliff and Cathy (Margot Robbie) have a tumultuous and toxic relationship. Heathcliff is surly, cruel, and vindictive. He emotionally terrorizes Isabella Linton (Alison Oliver) because he can‚Äôt have Cathy. So much so that at a certain point, Isabella crawls on the floor like a dog as he holds onto her collar and makes her bark. While Isabella seems to enjoy this roleplay, it‚Äôs uncomfortable to watch. It would take skill, care and precision to pull off this kind of sexual deviance and kink between a consenting couple, let alone between one with a problematic age gap, and power imbalance. I like how female desire is depicted through Isabella, but throw race into the mix and to be frank, I just don‚Äôt think Fennell has the range.¬†

Based on what scholars have deduced and what Bront√´ wrote, Heathcliff was probably Brown, which is interesting considering Fennell cast Pakistani-British actor Shazad Latif as Edgar Linton, Cathy‚Äôs husband, who was definitely white in the books. His race is barely acknowledged in the movie. And same goes for Hong Chau‚Äôs Nelly (played in youth by Vy Nguyen), Cathy‚Äôs live-in maid and best friend, also a white character who is now reimagined as Asian. There‚Äôs a brief mention of Nelly‚Äôs race, when Cathy‚Äôs father says something that implies she should be grateful he took her in. Otherwise, the way race would factor into their volatile friendship is never explored. In another writer-director‚Äôs hands, this story would be rife for mining the racial and class tensions of the era. With the right storyteller, I‚Äôm all for showing flawed characters of color in toxic relationships. They don‚Äôt have to be perfect representations of their race. But, again, I don‚Äôt think Fennell has any intention, or the competency, to tackle all of that in her work.¬†¬†

You realize early on what Fennell is doing. And that this Wuthering Heights is not a straightforward adaptation; it‚Äôs her own personal fantasy. She said as much on the red carpet for the LA premiere: ‚ÄúEveryone who loves this book has such a personal connection to it, and so you can only kind of ever make the movie that you sort of imagined yourself when you read it.‚Äù In Fennell‚Äôs fantasy, Heathcliff couldn‚Äôt possibly be anything but a tall, white man that looks like Elordi. Heathcliff is an object of desire and Fennell‚Äôs desires cannot extend beyond her worldview, and clearly, that world is very white. Which is fine, actually. She can make the movie she wants to. And I‚Äôd rather not watch a story told by a rich, white woman about the twisted proclivities of a Black or Brown man. I wouldn‚Äôt want to see it, and I wasn‚Äôt holding my breath waiting for it.¬†And it‚Äôs telling that in Fennell‚Äôs fantasy, the only people of color, Nelly and Edgar, are characters who Cathy uses and discards at her pleasure.

For the people enraged over this adaptation, I want to ask: what were you expecting? I‚Äôm not trying to be condescending, I just genuinely didn‚Äôt expect a nuanced rumination on class, race, desire, and abuse from this movie. I watched the trailers, heard Robbie and Fennell talk about the movie, and I‚Äôve seen Fennell‚Äôs previous films. I knew what they were trying to do with Wuthering Heights. It‚Äôs the spiritual equivalent to the genre of toxic white mess that unfolds in TV hits like Succession and The White Lotus. It‚Äôs a continuation of the recent trend of modern, magically race-bent, colorblind retellings of beloved literary works, like Netflix‚Äôs Bridgerton and Persuasion, and Apple TV‚Äôs The Buccaneers. It was never going to be that deep. But all art is political, so yes, while white filmmakers should know better and do better, I would rather spend my time championing original work from Black and Brown filmmakers and storytellers than wish for a non-white Heathcliff in Emerald Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights. I think that‚Äôs a waste of time. There is inevitably going to be an onslaught of thinkpieces and TikTok rants dedicated to chastising this casting. Sure, let‚Äôs call out whitewashing, but instead of expending all our energy on begging for scraps from white Hollywood, let‚Äôs support our own.¬†

I‚Äôd rather focus on making sure The Gilded Age gets 17 seasons (its co-showrunner is Sonja Warfield, a Black woman) and the upcoming adaptation of The Davenports (also brought to you by Warfield), gets all the hype it deserves than try to make this Wuthering Heights into something it was never going to be. I‚Äôd rather watch Amma Asante‚Äôs Belle again and support whatever work she‚Äôs got in the pipeline. I‚Äôd rather push for execs to greenlight anything and everything Nia DaCosta is going to do next. I‚Äôd rather uplift Alyssa Cole, Adrianna Herrera, Vanessa Riley, and the countless other Black and Brown woman historical romance writers than force Fennell to change her warped fantastical version of Heathcliff and Cathy‚Äôs ill-fated love story into anything other than what it is.¬†

So let‚Äôs get into what is onscreen and whether that is worth your time. This may surprise you, but I actually think it might be. When I settled into Fennell‚Äôs Wuthering Heights world, and got over the unnecessary shock tactic of that opening scene, I started to enjoy myself. For better and for worse, I was entertained. Elordi and Robbie (who the internet also swore was miscast because of her age) are electric together. I think their chemistry makes the whole thing worth it.

In the story that Fennell is telling, their chemistry is the one thing that needs to work, and it does. I believe that these two people would tear the world ‚Äî and themselves ‚Äî apart to be together. I also believe that they want to tear each other‚Äôs clothes off. They are so down bad for each other, inanimate objects that are slightly sexual set them ablaze. Chemistry often feels like a lost art and it was refreshing to see good, old-fashioned, horny-ass onscreen attraction. And for the first time, I understood the global thirst for Jacob Elordi. While Robbie‚Äôs Cathy is spunky, stubborn, and independent, Elordi‚Äôs Heathcliff is brooding, desperate, and clingy. He‚Äôs a real yearner and this may mean that I need some serious therapy, but I was into it.¬†

A friend of mine went to an early screening of the movie as well and his review was simply, ‚Äúgowns, beautiful gowns‚Äù and he‚Äôs not wrong, but I think it‚Äôs more than that. The costumes are absurd, but in this cinematic world, that‚Äôs a compliment! This movie thrives in absurdity and extravagance. There were moments when Robbie as Cathy walked into the frame and I had an audible reaction to her costume. Sure, at times, that took me out of the story, but if they were going to gasp-inducing costume design moments, they succeeded. Visually, Wuthering Heights is stunning. It nails the gloomy, overcast foreboding rolling hills that the source material describes while also injecting shots of color, humor, and exuberance into the film‚Äôs aesthetic. In spite of the depressing subject matter, this Wuthering Heights is more camp than melancholy.¬†

The film will probably never beat the style over substance accusations, understandably, but for me, the performances are the best part. Chau is perfectly exasperated and defiant. Latif is doting and oblivious yet likeable. Oliver is intoxicating and exhilarating to watch. And Elordi and Robbie lean so hard into the ‚Äúsmooth-brained sensuality‚Äù of Fennell‚Äôs adaptation that it‚Äôs not hard to believe they were obsessed with each other on set.¬†

The audiences who show up to the theater on Valentine‚Äôs Day hoping for a feel-good romance may leave a bit traumatized (just like I was when I first read Wuthering Heights in high school), but they‚Äôll also buy into the splendor and pageantry of this movie. And they‚Äôll understand why Elordi and Robbie are two of the most in-demand talents of their generation. I do wish that a Black-led, Black-directed film ‚Äî or one made by and for people of color ‚Äî was getting the same over-the-top treatment, star-making potential, and budget, but until we start yelling more about why we aren‚Äôt seeing those stories greenlit, funded, and released, we‚Äôll be stuck in our own fantasy. Fennell‚Äôs warped, whimsical, white-as-hell fever dream may be a compelling watch, but it‚Äôs her imagination come to life. I want to imagine a world in which the weird whims of Black and Brown filmmakers are able to be awakened too.
